Figure 2 shows the curve of œïi‚Å¢(ùê∞,ùúº,ùú∏)subscriptitalic-œïùëñùê∞ùúºùú∏\phi_{i}(\mathbf{w},\bm{\eta},\bm{\gamma})italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w , bold_italic_Œ∑ , bold_italic_Œ≥ ) across iùëñiitalic_i, where we vary cùëêcitalic_c from 0 to 5. Note that in the figure, we use œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to denote œïi‚Å¢(ùê∞,ùúº,ùú∏)subscriptitalic-œïùëñùê∞ùúºùú∏\phi_{i}(\mathbf{w},\bm{\eta},\bm{\gamma})italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_w , bold_italic_Œ∑ , bold_italic_Œ≥ ) for brevity. From Figure 2, one can observe that the value of œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is almost linear in the number of ratings iùëñiitalic_i. This implies that the speed of convergence is roughly exponential in the number of ratings iùëñiitalic_i. Figure 2(a) shows that œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases in cùëêcitalic_c when Œ≥=0ùõæ0\gamma=0italic_Œ≥ = 0. This implies that when there are no herding effects, the convergence speed of the simple unweighted average rule is faster than recency aware aggregation rules. However, when Œ≥=0.2ùõæ0.2\gamma=0.2italic_Œ≥ = 0.2 and Œ≥=0.4ùõæ0.4\gamma=0.4italic_Œ≥ = 0.4, œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT first increases and then decreases as we increase cùëêcitalic_c. This implies that in the presence of herding effects, recency aware aggregation rule can have faster speed of convergence. However, the strength of recency awareness should not be too strong. Furthermore, when Œ≥=0.2ùõæ0.2\gamma=0.2italic_Œ≥ = 0.2 and Œ≥=0.4ùõæ0.4\gamma=0.4italic_Œ≥ = 0.4, the aggregation rules with c=0.2ùëê0.2c=0.2italic_c = 0.2 and c=1ùëê1c=1italic_c = 1 have the highest convergence speed respectively. Namely, as the strength of herding effects increases, the online rating system operator can increase the strength of recency awareness to speed up convergence.

Impact of review selection mechanism (Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑). Recall that each review selection mechanism is modeled via a parameter Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ capturing the accuracy. Figure 3 shows œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as we vary Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ from 0 to 0.3. One can observe that œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases in Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑. This shows that increasing the accuracy of review selection mechanism can speed up the convergence. The improvement of œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes small, as we increase cùëêcitalic_c. This implies that an accurate review selection mechanism can improve the convergence speed significantly only when the strength of recency awareness of an aggregation rule is not very strong.

Impact of herding effects (Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥). Recall that the herding effects is modeled via a parameter Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ capturing the strength of herding. Figure 4 shows œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as we vary Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ from 0 to 0.3. One can observe that œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases in Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥. This shows that as users become more prone to herding effects, the speed of convergence slows down. The decrease of œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes small, as we increase cùëêcitalic_c. In other words, the rating aggregation rules having higher strength of recency awareness are more robust against herding effects.

Lessons learned. The recency aware aggregation rule can speed up the convergence over the simple unweighted average rule, but the strength of recency awareness should not be too strong. Increasing the the accuracy of a review selection mechanism can always improve the convergence speed, and this improvement decreases as the strength of recency awareness increases. Herding effects slow down the speed of convergence, but the aggregation rule with stronger strength of recency awareness can be more robust (in terms of convergence speed) against herding effects.

5.2. Evaluating the Inference Algorithm

Recall that ùú∂Nsubscriptùú∂ùëÅ\bm{\alpha}_{N}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≥~Nsubscript~ùõæùëÅ\tilde{\gamma}_{N}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the inferred model parameters. We aim to study the accuracy of ùú∂Nsubscriptùú∂ùëÅ\bm{\alpha}_{N}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≥~Nsubscript~ùõæùëÅ\tilde{\gamma}_{N}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in estimating the best linear approximation denoted by ùú∂l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùú∂‚àóùëôùëñùëõ\bm{\alpha}^{\ast}_{lin}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≥~l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àósubscriptsuperscript~ùõæ‚àóùëôùëñùëõ\tilde{\gamma}^{\ast}_{lin}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In general, the best linear approximation ùú∂l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùú∂‚àóùëôùëñùëõ\bm{\alpha}^{\ast}_{lin}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≥~l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àósubscriptsuperscript~ùõæ‚àóùëôùëñùëõ\tilde{\gamma}^{\ast}_{lin}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is determined by the specific form of ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha}bold_italic_Œ± and ùúΩisubscriptùúΩùëñ\bm{\theta}_{i}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For simplicity, here we consider approximating a linear model, which is specified in Section 5.1, i.e., ùúΩisubscriptùúΩùëñ\bm{\theta}_{i}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT derived in Equation (2), Œ∑i=Œ∑subscriptùúÇùëñùúÇ\eta_{i}=\etaitalic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Œ∑ and Œ≥i=Œ≥subscriptùõæùëñùõæ\gamma_{i}=\gammaitalic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Œ≥. Then the best linear approximation for this linear model is ùú∂l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àó=ùú∂,Œ≥~l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àó=(1‚àíŒ∑)‚Å¢Œ≥.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùú∂‚àóùëôùëñùëõùú∂subscriptsuperscript~ùõæ‚àóùëôùëñùëõ1ùúÇùõæ\bm{\alpha}^{\ast}_{lin}=\bm{\alpha},\tilde{\gamma}^{\ast}_{lin}=(1-\eta)\gamma.bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Œ± , over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_Œ∑ ) italic_Œ≥ . We define the relative estimation error as

(6) EŒ±‚âúùîº‚Å¢[‚Äñùú∂N‚àíùú∂l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àó‚Äñ1]‚Äñùú∂l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àó‚Äñ1,‚âúsubscriptùê∏ùõºùîºdelimited-[]subscriptnormsubscriptùú∂ùëÅsubscriptsuperscriptùú∂‚àóùëôùëñùëõ1subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptùú∂‚àóùëôùëñùëõ1\displaystyle E_{\alpha}{\triangleq}\frac{\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bm{\alpha}_{% N}-\bm{\alpha}^{\ast}_{lin}\right\|_{1}\right]}{\left\|\bm{\alpha}^{\ast}_{lin% }\right\|_{1}},italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú divide start_ARG blackboard_E [ ‚à• bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG start_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , EŒ≥‚âúùîº‚Å¢[|Œ≥~N‚àíŒ≥~l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àó|]Œ≥~l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àó.‚âúsubscriptùê∏ùõæùîºdelimited-[]subscript~ùõæùëÅsubscriptsuperscript~ùõæ‚àóùëôùëñùëõsubscriptsuperscript~ùõæ‚àóùëôùëñùëõ\displaystyle E_{\gamma}{\triangleq}\frac{\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\tilde{\gamma}% _{N}-\tilde{\gamma}^{\ast}_{lin}\right|\right]}{\tilde{\gamma}^{\ast}_{lin}}.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú divide start_ARG blackboard_E [ | over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ] end_ARG start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG .

We calculate EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT via the Monte Carlo simulation. For each round of simulation, we use our model (with parameters ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha}bold_italic_Œ±, Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑, Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ and cùëêcitalic_c, which will be specified later) to generate NùëÅNitalic_N ratings. Inputting these NùëÅNitalic_N ratings to our inference algorithm stated in Section 4.2, we obtain ùú∂Nsubscriptùú∂ùëÅ\bm{\alpha}_{N}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≥~Nsubscript~ùõæùëÅ\tilde{\gamma}_{N}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for one round. Then, we compute one sample of EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT via Equation (6). We repeat this process for multiple rounds to obtain multiple samples of EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Lastly, we use the average of these samples to estimate EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Figure 5 shows EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT across the number of ratings NùëÅNitalic_N under both the honest rating and misbehaving rating scenarios, where we set ùú∂=[0,0,0.1,0.4,0.5]ùú∂000.10.40.5\bm{\alpha}=[0,0,0.1,0.4,0.5]bold_italic_Œ± = [ 0 , 0 , 0.1 , 0.4 , 0.5 ], (1‚àíŒ∑)‚Å¢Œ≥=0.81ùúÇùõæ0.8(1-\eta)\gamma=0.8( 1 - italic_Œ∑ ) italic_Œ≥ = 0.8 and c=0.ùëê0c=0.italic_c = 0 . We consider a large effective strength of herding effects (1‚àíŒ∑)‚Å¢Œ≥=0.81ùúÇùõæ0.8(1-\eta)\gamma=0.8( 1 - italic_Œ∑ ) italic_Œ≥ = 0.8, because the robustness of our inference algorithm (against misbehaving ratings) under small strength can be implied by this large strength. Figure 5(a) shows that under the honest rating scenario, both EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decrease in the number of rating NùëÅNitalic_N. This implies that the accuracy of our inference algorithm increases as more ratings are observed. Furthermore, the curve of EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT lies above EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This means that our inference algorithm has a higher accuracy in estimating the ground-truth collective opinion ùú∂l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùú∂‚àóùëôùëñùëõ\bm{\alpha}^{\ast}_{lin}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT than the effective strength of herding effects Œ≥~l‚Å¢i‚Å¢n‚àósubscriptsuperscript~ùõæ‚àóùëôùëñùëõ\tilde{\gamma}^{\ast}_{lin}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The error EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be as small as 10% and 20% respectively with thousands of ratings. Figure 5(b) presents EŒ±subscriptùê∏ùõºE_{\alpha}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and EŒ≥subscriptùê∏ùõæE_{\gamma}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when we inject 50 misbehaving ratings (i.e., ‚Ñê={51,‚Ä¶,100}‚Ñê51‚Ä¶100\mathcal{I}=\{51,\ldots,100\}caligraphic_I = { 51 , ‚Ä¶ , 100 }) of 5. Compared to Figure 5(a), one can observe that our inference algorithm has similar accuracy as that of the honest rating case. This implies that our inference algorithm is robust against misbehaving ratings.

Lessons learned. Our inference algorithm can achieve a high accuracy under thousands of ratings and it is robust against misbehaving ratings.

6. Experiments on Real Data

We conduct experiments on real-world online ratings from Amazon and TripAdvisor. We identify recency aware rating aggregation rules, which improve the convergence speed in Amazon and TripAdvisor by 41% and 62% respectively.

6.1. Datasets and Parameter Inference.

We use the ratings of 32,888 products in Amazon and 11,543 hotels in TripAdvisor crawled in 2013. From the rating dataset we select the items (i.e., products in Amazon or hotels in TripAdvisor) with at least 2,000 ratings to attain a balance between inference accuracy and dataset scale. In total, 284 products in the Amazon dataset and 111 hotels in TripAdvisor dataset are selected. Note that Amazon and TripAdvisor use the simple unweighted average rule, i.e., wi=ic,c=0formulae-sequencesubscriptùë§ùëñsuperscriptùëñùëêùëê0w_{i}=i^{c},c=0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c = 0. We apply the Algorithm stated in Section 4 to infer ùú∂Nsubscriptùú∂ùëÅ\bm{\alpha}_{N}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≥~Nsubscript~ùõæùëÅ\tilde{\gamma}_{N}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each selected item.

Figure 8 shows the cumulative distribution (CDF) of the inferred effective herding strength Œ≥~Nsubscript~ùõæùëÅ\tilde{\gamma}_{N}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT across items. One can observe that the cumulative distribution curve of Amazon lies above that of TripAdvisor roughly. The average of the inferred effective herding strengths for Amazon and TripAdvisor are 0.3660.3660.3660.366 and 0.4160.4160.4160.416 respectively. This implies that users in Tripadvisor are more likely to follow the crowd in providing ratings.

6.2. Rating Aggregation Rules and Implications

We consider wi=icsubscriptùë§ùëñsuperscriptùëñùëêw_{i}=i^{c}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Figure 9 shows the value of œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as we vary cùëêcitalic_c from 0 to 4. Note that the Amazon and TripAdvisor practice c=0ùëê0c=0italic_c = 0, i.e., unweighted aggregation rule. One can observe that we can improve the speed of convergence in Amzaon by 3919/2785‚àí1=41%391927851percent413919/2785-1=41\%3919 / 2785 - 1 = 41 % using a recency aware aggregation rule with c=0.5ùëê0.5c=0.5italic_c = 0.5 and speed up the convergence in TripAdvisor by 3266/2011‚àí1=62%326620111percent623266/2011-1=62\%3266 / 2011 - 1 = 62 % using a recency aware aggregation rule with c=0.8ùëê0.8c=0.8italic_c = 0.8. In other words, using these aggregation rules, we can reveal the ground-truth quality of products with the same accuracy by using significantly less ratings in both Amazon and TripAdvisor.

Lessons learned. We identify appropriate recency aware aggregation rules, which can improve the speed of convergence in Amazon and TripAdvisor by 41% and 62%.

7. Experiments on Real Data

We conduct experiments on real-world online ratings from Amazon and TripAdvisor. We identify recency aware rating aggregation rules, which improve the convergence speed in Amazon and TripAdvisor by 41% and 62% respectively.

7.1. Datasets and Parameter Inference.

We use the ratings of 32,888 products in Amazon and 11,543 hotels in TripAdvisor crawled in 2013. From the rating dataset we select the items (i.e., products in Amazon or hotels in TripAdvisor) with at least 2,000 ratings to attain a balance between inference accuracy and dataset scale. In total, 284 products in the Amazon dataset and 111 hotels in TripAdvisor dataset are selected. Note that Amazon and TripAdvisor use the simple unweighted average rule, i.e., wi=ic,c=0formulae-sequencesubscriptùë§ùëñsuperscriptùëñùëêùëê0w_{i}=i^{c},c=0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c = 0. We apply the Algorithm stated in Section 4 to infer ùú∂Nsubscriptùú∂ùëÅ\bm{\alpha}_{N}bold_italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≥~Nsubscript~ùõæùëÅ\tilde{\gamma}_{N}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each selected item.

Figure 8 shows the cumulative distribution (CDF) of the inferred effective herding strength Œ≥~Nsubscript~ùõæùëÅ\tilde{\gamma}_{N}over~ start_ARG italic_Œ≥ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT across items. One can observe that the cumulative distribution curve of Amazon lies above that of TripAdvisor roughly. The average of the inferred effective herding strengths for Amazon and TripAdvisor are 0.3660.3660.3660.366 and 0.4160.4160.4160.416 respectively. This implies that users in Tripadvisor are more likely to follow the crowd in providing ratings.

7.2. Rating Aggregation Rules and Implications

We consider wi=icsubscriptùë§ùëñsuperscriptùëñùëêw_{i}=i^{c}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Figure 9 shows the value of œïisubscriptitalic-œïùëñ\phi_{i}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as we vary cùëêcitalic_c from 0 to 4. Note that the Amazon and TripAdvisor practice c=0ùëê0c=0italic_c = 0, i.e., unweighted aggregation rule. One can observe that we can improve the speed of convergence in Amzaon by 3919/2785‚àí1=41%391927851percent413919/2785-1=41\%3919 / 2785 - 1 = 41 % using a recency aware aggregation rule with c=0.5ùëê0.5c=0.5italic_c = 0.5 and speed up the convergence in TripAdvisor by 3266/2011‚àí1=62%326620111percent623266/2011-1=62\%3266 / 2011 - 1 = 62 % using a recency aware aggregation rule with c=0.8ùëê0.8c=0.8italic_c = 0.8. In other words, using these aggregation rules, we can reveal the ground-truth quality of products with the same accuracy by using significantly less ratings in both Amazon and TripAdvisor.

Lessons learned. We identify appropriate recency aware aggregation rules, which can improve the speed of convergence in Amazon and TripAdvisor by 41% and 62%.

8. Application: Rating Prediction

To demonstrate the versatility of our model, we parametrize our model to predict subsequent ratings. We apply regularized least square to infer model parameters. Extensive experiments on four datasets demonstrate that our model can improve the accuracy of Herd and the HIALF .

8.1. Applying Our Models to Rating Prediction

We consider the following rating prediction problem: given a set of historical ratings of items, predict subsequent ratings of items. To apply our model to address this problem, we next first parameterize our model and then infer model parameters.

Let ru,i‚àà‚Ñ≥subscriptùëüùë¢ùëñ‚Ñ≥r_{u,i}\in\mathcal{M}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà caligraphic_M denote the ubiased rating of user u‚ààùí∞ùë¢ùí∞u\in\mathcal{U}italic_u ‚àà caligraphic_U toward i‚àà‚Ñêùëñ‚Ñêi\in\mathcal{I}italic_i ‚àà caligraphic_I. Namely, ru,isubscriptùëüùë¢ùëñr_{u,i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT characterizes user uùë¢uitalic_u‚Äôs intrinsic overall opinion toward item iùëñiitalic_i

Modeling initial opinion formation. Now we model the initial opinion formation, i.e., the function Œìu‚Å¢(‚Ñãi,k)subscriptŒìùë¢subscript‚Ñãùëñùëò\Gamma_{u}(\mathcal{H}_{i,k})roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Users may form initial opinions from the aggregation of historical ratings or a small number of latest ratings. We first consider the case that users form initial opinions from the aggregation of historical ratings. Denote the collective opinion summarized from the rating history ‚Ñãi,ksubscript‚Ñãùëñùëò\mathcal{H}_{i,k}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as

ùíâi,k‚âú[hi,k,1,‚Ä¶,hi,k,M],‚âúsubscriptùíâùëñùëòsubscript‚Ñéùëñùëò1‚Ä¶subscript‚ÑéùëñùëòùëÄ\bm{h}_{i,k}\!\triangleq\![h_{i,k,1},\ldots,h_{i,k,M}],bold_italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú [ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,

where hi,k,m‚àà[0,1]subscript‚Ñéùëñùëòùëö01h_{i,k,m}\in[0,1]italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà [ 0 , 1 ] and ‚àëm‚àà‚Ñ≥hi,k,m=1subscriptùëö‚Ñ≥subscript‚Ñéùëñùëòùëö1\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}h_{i,k,m}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ‚àà caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. The ùíâi,ksubscriptùíâùëñùëò\bm{h}_{i,k}bold_italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is public to all users. We consider a class of weighted aggregation rules to summarize historical ratings:

(7) hi,k,m=‚àëj=1kŒ±j‚Å¢ùïÄ{Ri,j=m}‚àëj=1kŒ±j,subscript‚Ñéùëñùëòùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëòùëó1subscriptùõºùëósubscriptùïÄsubscriptùëÖùëñùëóùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëòùëó1subscriptùõºùëó\displaystyle h_{i,k,m}=\frac{\sum^{k}_{j=1}\alpha_{j}\mathbb{I}_{\{R_{i,j}=m% \}}}{\sum^{k}_{j=1}\alpha_{j}},italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

where Œ±j‚àà‚Ñù+subscriptùõºùëósubscript‚Ñù\alpha_{j}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the weight associated with jùëójitalic_j-th rating, and ùïÄùïÄ\mathbb{I}blackboard_I is an indicator function. For example, Œ±j=1,‚àÄjsubscriptùõºùëó1for-allùëó\alpha_{j}\!=\!1,\forall jitalic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , ‚àÄ italic_j, is deployed in Amazon and TripAdvisor, which corresponds to ‚Äúaverage rating rule‚Äù. Under this average rating rule, we have hi,k,m=‚àëj=1kùïÄ{Ri,j=m}/ksubscript‚Ñéùëñùëòùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëòùëó1subscriptùïÄsubscriptùëÖùëñùëóùëöùëòh_{i,k,m}\!=\!\sum^{k}_{j=1}\mathbb{I}_{\{R_{i,j}=m\}}/kitalic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_k, which is the fraction of historical ratings equal mùëömitalic_m. Note that ùíâi,ksubscriptùíâùëñùëò\bm{h}_{i,k}bold_italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is displayed to all users. We capture the aggregate opinion heterogeneity in initial opinion formation as follows:

(8) Œìu‚Å¢(‚Ñãi,k)=‚àëm‚àà‚Ñ≥m‚Å¢Œ≤m‚Å¢hi,k,m‚àëm‚àà‚Ñ≥Œ≤m‚Å¢hi,k,m,subscriptŒìùë¢subscript‚Ñãùëñùëòsubscriptùëö‚Ñ≥ùëösubscriptùõΩùëösubscript‚Ñéùëñùëòùëösubscriptùëö‚Ñ≥subscriptùõΩùëösubscript‚Ñéùëñùëòùëö\displaystyle\Gamma_{u}(\mathcal{H}_{i,k})=\frac{\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}m\beta_% {m}h_{i,k,m}}{\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\beta_{m}h_{i,k,m}},roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ‚àà caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m ‚àà caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

where the weight Œ≤m‚àà[0,1]subscriptùõΩùëö01\beta_{m}\in[0,1]italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà [ 0 , 1 ] models how a user weighs the opinion associated with each rating level. For example, a user may assign a large weight to low ratings representing that she is sensitive to negative opinions. There are several possible parametric forms of the weights:

Œ≤m=exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥‚Å¢m),Œ≤m=mŒ≥,Œ≤m=ln‚Å°(mŒ≥+1).formulae-sequencesubscriptùõΩùëöùõæùëöformulae-sequencesubscriptùõΩùëösuperscriptùëöùõæsubscriptùõΩùëösuperscriptùëöùõæ1\beta_{m}=\exp(-\gamma m),\,\,\,\beta_{m}=m^{\gamma},\,\,\,\beta_{m}=\ln(m^{% \gamma}+1).italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_Œ≥ italic_m ) , italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_ln ( italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 ) .

where Œ≥‚àà‚Ñùùõæ‚Ñù\gamma\in\mathbb{R}italic_Œ≥ ‚àà blackboard_R.

Now, we consider the case that users form initial opinions from a small number of latest ratings. Let n‚àà‚Ñï+ùëõsubscript‚Ñïn\in\mathbb{N}_{+}italic_n ‚àà blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the number of latest ratings that users refer to for initial opinion formation. We capture rating recency in initial opinion formation as:

(9) Œìu‚Å¢(‚Ñãi,k)=‚àëj=1nŒ∑k,j‚Å¢Ri,k‚àíj+1‚Å¢ùïÄ{k‚àíj+1‚â•1}‚àëj=1nŒ∑k,j‚Å¢ùïÄ{k‚àíj+1‚â•1},subscriptŒìùë¢subscript‚Ñãùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëõsubscriptùúÇùëòùëósubscriptùëÖùëñùëòùëó1subscriptùïÄùëòùëó11superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëõsubscriptùúÇùëòùëósubscriptùïÄùëòùëó11\displaystyle\Gamma_{u}(\mathcal{H}_{i,k})=\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{n}\eta_{k,j}R_{i,% k-j+1}\mathbb{I}_{\{k-j+1\geq 1\}}}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}\eta_{k,j}\mathbb{I}_{\{k-j+% 1\geq 1\}}},roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k - italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_k - italic_j + 1 ‚â• 1 } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_k - italic_j + 1 ‚â• 1 } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

where the weight satisfies Œ∑k,j‚àà‚Ñù+subscriptùúÇùëòùëósubscript‚Ñù\eta_{k,j}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and we set Ri,j=0subscriptùëÖùëñùëó0R_{i,j}=0italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all j<1ùëó1j<1italic_j < 1 by default. There are several possible forms of the weight Œ∑k,jsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó\eta_{k,j}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. One can use the following forms of Œ∑k,jsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó\eta_{k,j}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to model arrival order aware initial opinion formation:

Œ∑k,j=exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ∂‚Å¢j),Œ∑k,j=1jŒ∂,Œ∑k,j=1Œ∂‚Å¢ln‚Å°(j+1).formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÇùëòùëóùúÅùëóformulae-sequencesubscriptùúÇùëòùëó1superscriptùëóùúÅsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó1ùúÅùëó1\eta_{k,j}=\exp(-\zeta j),\,\,\,\eta_{k,j}=\frac{1}{j^{\zeta}},\,\,\,\eta_{k,j% }=\frac{1}{\zeta\ln(j+1)}.italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_Œ∂ italic_j ) , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∂ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∂ roman_ln ( italic_j + 1 ) end_ARG .

where Œ∂‚àà‚ÑùùúÅ‚Ñù\zeta\in\mathbb{R}italic_Œ∂ ‚àà blackboard_R. One can use the following forms of Œ∑k,jsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó\eta_{k,j}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to model arrival time stamp aware initial opinion formation:

Œ∑k,j=exp‚Å°(‚àíœÅ‚Å¢(tu‚àíti,k+1‚àíj)Œ¥),Œ∑k,j=1(tu‚àíti,k+1‚àíj)œÅformulae-sequencesubscriptùúÇùëòùëóùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùë¢subscriptùë°ùëñùëò1ùëóùõøsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó1superscriptsubscriptùë°ùë¢subscriptùë°ùëñùëò1ùëóùúå\displaystyle\eta_{k,j}=\exp\left(-\rho(t_{u}-t_{i,k+1-j})^{\delta}\right),\,% \,\,\eta_{k,j}=\frac{1}{(t_{u}-t_{i,k+1-j})^{\rho}}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_œÅ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k + 1 - italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k + 1 - italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG
Œ∑k,j=1œÅ‚Å¢ln‚Å°(tu‚àíti,k+1‚àíj+1).subscriptùúÇùëòùëó1ùúåsubscriptùë°ùë¢subscriptùë°ùëñùëò1ùëó1\displaystyle\eta_{k,j}=\frac{1}{\rho\ln(t_{u}-t_{i,k+1-j}+1)}.italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÅ roman_ln ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k + 1 - italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 ) end_ARG .

where tusubscriptùë°ùë¢t_{u}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the arrival time of user uùë¢uitalic_u, Œ¥‚àà‚Ñù,œÅ‚àà‚Ñùformulae-sequenceùõø‚Ñùùúå‚Ñù\delta\in\mathbb{R},\rho\in\mathbb{R}italic_Œ¥ ‚àà blackboard_R , italic_œÅ ‚àà blackboard_R, we set ti,j=0subscriptùë°ùëñùëó0t_{i,j}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 by default for all j<1ùëó1j<1italic_j < 1.

Model parameterization. The Herd algorithm was proposed by Wang et al. , which is the first algorithm exploring Herd effects to improve rating prediction. We will use Herd as a major comparison baseline. For fair comparison with Herd , we parameterize ru,isubscriptùëüùë¢ùëñr_{u,i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT via the classical latent factor (LF) model :

(10) ru,i=ùíôuT‚Å¢ùíöi+bi+bu+g.subscriptùëüùë¢ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíôùë¢ùëásubscriptùíöùëñsubscriptùëèùëñsubscriptùëèùë¢ùëîr_{u,i}=\bm{x}_{u}^{T}\bm{y}_{i}+b_{i}+b_{u}+g.italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_g .

In Equation (10), ùíôu‚àà‚ÑùŒ∫subscriptùíôùë¢superscript‚ÑùùúÖ\bm{x}_{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{\kappa}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∫ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùíöi‚àà‚ÑùŒ∫subscriptùíöùëñsuperscript‚ÑùùúÖ\bm{y}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{\kappa}bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∫ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represent vectors of latent features for user uùë¢uitalic_u and product pùëùpitalic_p, where Œ∫‚àà‚Ñï+ùúÖsubscript‚Ñï\kappa\in\mathbb{N}_{+}italic_Œ∫ ‚àà blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The bu‚àà‚Ñùsubscriptùëèùë¢‚Ñùb_{u}\in\mathbb{R}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R and bi‚àà‚Ñùsubscriptùëèùëñ‚Ñùb_{i}\in\mathbb{R}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R model user and product bias respectively. The g‚àà‚Ñùùëî‚Ñùg\in\mathbb{R}italic_g ‚àà blackboard_R models the constant shift or residual. All parameters in Equation (10) are unknown and will be inferred from the data. Similarily, we parametrize the strength of herding effects as:

su,k=21+exp‚Å°(‚àísùí∞2√ók)‚àí1subscriptùë†ùë¢ùëò21superscriptsubscriptùë†ùí∞2ùëò1s_{u,k}=\frac{2}{1+\exp(-{s_{\mathcal{U}}}^{2}\times k)}-1italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + roman_exp ( - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT √ó italic_k ) end_ARG - 1

where sùí∞‚àà‚Ñùsubscriptùë†ùí∞‚Ñùs_{\mathcal{U}}\in\mathbb{R}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R is unknown parameters to be inferred from data. Note this parametrization method was used in , and we choose it for fair comparison with Herd. We will show that our model can outperform all the baselines. This implies that if one selects them with finer tuning, our model can achieve better performance. We summarize all parameters to be inferred from data as

ùíµ‚âú{g,{bi,ùíöi}i‚àà‚Ñê,{bu,ùíôu}u‚ààùí∞,sùí∞}‚âúùíµùëîsubscriptsubscriptùëèùëñsubscriptùíöùëñùëñ‚Ñêsubscriptsubscriptùëèùë¢subscriptùíôùë¢ùë¢ùí∞subscriptùë†ùí∞\mathcal{Z}\triangleq\left\{g,\{{b_{i}},{\bm{y}_{i}}\}_{i\in\mathcal{I}},\{{b_% {u}},{\bm{x}_{u}}\}_{u\in\mathcal{U}},s_{\mathcal{U}}\right\}caligraphic_Z ‚âú { italic_g , { italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà caligraphic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ‚àà caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }

All the hyper parameters will be given before model training.

Model inference. Consider a training rating dataset, in which product pùëùpitalic_p has Ki‚â•0subscriptùêæùëñ0K_{i}\geq 0italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 historical ratings. We aim to infer ùíµùíµ\mathcal{Z}caligraphic_Z from the training rating dataset. In particular, we use regularized least square method to infer ùíµùíµ\mathcal{Z}caligraphic_Z:

minùíµ‚Å¢‚àëi‚àà‚Ñê‚àëk=1Kisubscriptùíµsubscriptùëñ‚Ñêsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùêæùëñùëò1\displaystyle\min_{\mathcal{Z}}\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\sum\nolimits^{K% _{i}}_{k=1}roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà caligraphic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ru,i,k\displaystyle\bigg{[}r_{u,i,k}[ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
‚àí((21+exp‚Å°(‚àísùí∞√ók)‚àí1)√óŒìu(‚Ñãi,k)\displaystyle-\bigg{(}(\frac{2}{1+\exp(-s_{\mathcal{U}}\times k)}-1)\times% \Gamma_{u}(\mathcal{H}_{i,k})- ( ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + roman_exp ( - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó italic_k ) end_ARG - 1 ) √ó roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
+(1‚àí(21+exp‚Å°(‚àísùí∞√ók)‚àí1))121subscriptùë†ùí∞ùëò1\displaystyle+(1-(\frac{2}{1+\exp(-s_{\mathcal{U}}\times k)}-1))+ ( 1 - ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + roman_exp ( - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT √ó italic_k ) end_ARG - 1 ) )
√ó(ùíôuTùíöi+bi+bu+g))]2\displaystyle\times(\bm{x}_{u}^{T}\bm{y}_{i}+b_{i}+b_{u}+g)\bigg{)}\bigg{]}^{2}√ó ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_g ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
+Œªr‚Å¢e‚Å¢c‚Å¢(bu2+bi2+‚Äñùíôu‚Äñ22+‚Äñùíöi‚Äñ22)subscriptùúÜùëüùëíùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùë¢2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëñ2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùíôùë¢22superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùíöùëñ22\displaystyle+\lambda_{rec}(b_{u}^{2}+b_{i}^{2}+||\bm{x}_{u}||_{2}^{2}+||\bm{y% }_{i}||_{2}^{2})+ italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + | | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + | | bold_italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
+Œªs‚Å¢(sùí∞2)subscriptùúÜùë†superscriptsubscriptùë†ùí∞2\displaystyle+\lambda_{s}(s_{\mathcal{U}}^{2})+ italic_Œª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

We use stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm to learn model parameters ùíµùíµ\mathcal{Z}caligraphic_Z. Note that SGD was widely used in previous works to improve training efficiency

Rating prediction. Let ùíµ^^ùíµ\widehat{\mathcal{Z}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_Z end_ARG denote the inferred model parameter set. To illustrate, suppose we are going to predict the iùëñiitalic_i-th rating of item iùëñiitalic_i, i.e., Ri,ksubscriptùëÖùëñùëòR_{i,k}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that uk,isubscriptùë¢ùëòùëñu_{k,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the user who assign the rating Ri,ksubscriptùëÖùëñùëòR_{i,k}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We are given the ID of the user denoted by uk,isubscriptùë¢ùëòùëñu_{k,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then we predict the rating Ri,ksubscriptùëÖùëñùëòR_{i,k}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as r^uk,i,isubscript^ùëüsubscriptùë¢ùëòùëñùëñ\widehat{r}_{u_{k,i},i}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are computed using our model with the inferred parameters ùíµ^^ùíµ\widehat{\mathcal{Z}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_Z end_ARG. We denote our rating prediction method as R-HE.

8.2. Evaluation Settings

The dataset. We use four public datasets to evaluate the accuracy of our AC-RP method, whose overall statistics are summarized in Table 1. The dataset from Amazon was published in and it contains historical ratings of movies in Amazon. The dataset from Google Local was published in and it contains reviews about businesses from Google Local (Google Maps). The dataset from TripAdvisor was published in , and it contains historical ratings of hotels in TripAdvisor. The dataset from Yelp was downloaded from the link 222https://www.yelp.com/dataset and it contains historical ratings for restaurants in Yelp.

For fair comparison with Herd, we use the same method as HIALF (Zhang2019, ) to extract training dataset and testing dataset. Similar with HIALF , for each item in Table 1, we only select items with an medium positive average rating, i.e., average rating in the range [3.9,4.1]3.94.1[3.9,4.1][ 3.9 , 4.1 ] out. For each selected item we extract all its ratings and the associated users out. We then remove items with less than 50 training ratings, to avoid over-fitting. Table 2 summarizes overall statistics of the selected data. One can observe that after this selection, some datasets still contain around two hundred thousands of users. Comparing the number of ratings with the number of users, one can observe that the rating matrix is very sparse. Similar with HIALF , we further aggregate users with twenty ratings (or fifty) as a big user for Googlelocal and TripAdvisor ( or Amazon-movie and Yelp). Furthermore, for each selected item, we use its last 25 ratings as test ratings and use all other ratings as training ratings. We train the models on the training dataset, and validate the model on the testing dataset.

Comparison baseline & metrics. We use the root mean squared error (RMSE) to quantify the testing accuracy:

(11) R‚Å¢M‚Å¢S‚Å¢E=‚àëp‚ààùí´‚àëk=Kp‚àí24Kp(r^up,i,p,i‚àíRp,i)225‚Å¢|ùí´|,ùëÖùëÄùëÜùê∏subscriptùëùùí´subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùêæùëùùëòsubscriptùêæùëù24superscriptsubscript^ùëüsubscriptùë¢ùëùùëñùëùùëñsubscriptùëÖùëùùëñ225ùí´RMSE=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{p\in\mathcal{P}}\sum^{K_{p}}_{k=K_{p}-24}(\widehat{r}_{% u_{p,i},p,i}-R_{p,i})^{2}}{25|\mathcal{P}|}},italic_R italic_M italic_S italic_E = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ‚àà caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 24 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 25 | caligraphic_P | end_ARG end_ARG ,

where r^up,i,p,isubscript^ùëüsubscriptùë¢ùëùùëñùëùùëñ\widehat{r}_{u_{p,i},p,i}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes an estimation of rup,i,p,isubscriptùëüsubscriptùë¢ùëùùëñùëùùëñr_{u_{p,i},p,i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is computed using our model with the inferred parameters ùíµ^^ùíµ\widehat{\mathcal{Z}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_Z end_ARG. We compare our AC-RP method with the following three baselines.

  • ‚Ä¢

    HIALF . The HIALF algorithm was proposed by Zhang et al. , which is the first algorithm exploring assimilate-contrast effects to improve rating prediction.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Herd . The Herd algorithm was proposed by Zhang et al., which explores herding effects to improve rating prediction.

Parameter setting. To prevent over fitting, we set appropriate regularization hyper parameters for our models. Following similar principle in HIALF , we consider the regularization hyper parameters summarized in Table 3. Following previous work , we choose the dimension of latent features as Œ∫=5ùúÖ5\kappa=5italic_Œ∫ = 5. For the other hyper parameters, we will select them systematically and present them with the experiment results.

8.3. Rating Recency for Rating Prediction

In this section, we evaluate the benefit of exploiting rating recency for rating prediction tasks. Consider that under rating recency, users form initial opinion from nùëõnitalic_n latest ratings. We consider the initial opinion formation model derived in Equation

Impact of nùëõnitalic_n. The initial opinion is the simple average of nùëõnitalic_n latest ratings, i.e., Œ∑k,j=1,‚àÄjsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó1for-allùëó\eta_{k,j}=1,\forall jitalic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , ‚àÄ italic_j. Table 4 shows the RMSE of Herd, HIALF and our B-HE method. In Table 4, the column n=20,40,80ùëõ204080n=20,40,80italic_n = 20 , 40 , 80 corresponds to the RMSE of our B-HE method with n=20,40,80ùëõ204080n=20,40,80italic_n = 20 , 40 , 80. One can observe that when n=20ùëõ20n=20italic_n = 20, our method has a smaller RMSE than Herd. This statement also holds when n=40,80ùëõ4080n=40,80italic_n = 40 , 80. Namely, under some simple selections of nùëõnitalic_n, our method has a higher rating prediction accuracy than Herd. Note that this improvement of rating prediction accuracy by exploiting rating recency is supported by survey studies, which identified that users tend to read a small number of latest reviews or ratings to form initial opinions . The RMSE of our method varies as we increase nùëõnitalic_n from 20 to 80, This implies that nùëõnitalic_n is an important factor for the rating prediction accuracy and one needs to exploit the rating recency carefully for rating prediction. The above improvement on the rating prediction accuracy is achieved at simple selections of nùëõnitalic_n. One may further improve the rating prediction accuracy by finer tuning of nùëõnitalic_n. In this experiment, the initial opinion is the simple average of nùëõnitalic_n latest ratings. Users may have different weights to different ratings, i.e., more weights on more recent ratings. In the following, we explore this direction.

Impact of arrival order. The are two types of weights on ratings, i.e., based on arrival order and based on arrival time stamp of ratings. Here we study the weight which is based on arrival order. We fix n=20ùëõ20n=20italic_n = 20. To study the impact of arrival order, we consider three types of weights associated with the arrival order of ratings, i.e., exponential, polynomial and logarithmic in the arrival order, which are stated in Table 5. Table 5 shows that RMSE of our R-BE method under these three types of weights. Consider that the weight Œ∑k,jsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó\eta_{k,j}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is exponential in the arrival order, i.e., Œ∑k,j=exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ∂‚Å¢j)subscriptùúÇùëòùëóùúÅùëó\eta_{k,j}=\exp(-\zeta j)italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_Œ∂ italic_j ). One can observe that as we vary the parameter Œ∂ùúÅ\zetaitalic_Œ∂ of Œ∑k,j=exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ∂‚Å¢j)subscriptùúÇùëòùëóùúÅùëó\eta_{k,j}=\exp(-\zeta j)italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_Œ∂ italic_j ) from 0.01 to 0.0001, the RMSE can be further reduced over the unweighted case, i.e., Œ∂=0ùúÅ0\zeta=0italic_Œ∂ = 0. Similar observations can be found when the weight Œ∑k,jsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó\eta_{k,j}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is polynomial or logarithmic in the arrival order of ratings. This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival order. This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings Furthermore, this improvement is achieved at simple selections of the weight of ratings. One can further improve the rating prediction accuracy by finer tuning of weights.

Impact of arrival time stamp. We fix n=20ùëõ20n=20italic_n = 20. To study the impact of arrival time stamp, we consider three types of weights associated with the arrival time stamp of ratings, i.e., exponential, polynomial and logarithmic in the arrival time stamp, which are stated in Table 6. Table 6 shows that RMSE of our R-BE method under these three types of weights. Consider that the weight Œ∑k,jsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó\eta_{k,j}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is exponential in the arrival time stamp, i.e., Œ∑k,j=exp‚Å°(‚àíœÅ‚Å¢(tu‚àíti,k+1‚àíj)0.4)subscriptùúÇùëòùëóùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùë¢subscriptùë°ùëñùëò1ùëó0.4\eta_{k,j}=\exp(-\rho(t_{u}-t_{i,k+1-j})^{0.4})italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_œÅ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k + 1 - italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). One can observe that as we vary the parameter œÅùúå\rhoitalic_œÅ of Œ∑k,j=exp‚Å°(‚àíœÅ‚Å¢(tu‚àíti,k+1‚àíj)0.4)subscriptùúÇùëòùëóùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùë¢subscriptùë°ùëñùëò1ùëó0.4\eta_{k,j}=\exp(-\rho(t_{u}-t_{i,k+1-j})^{0.4})italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_œÅ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_k + 1 - italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) from 0.01 to 0.0001, the RMSE can be further reduced over the unweighted case, i.e., œÅ=0ùúå0\rho=0italic_œÅ = 0. Similar observations can be found when the weight Œ∑k,jsubscriptùúÇùëòùëó\eta_{k,j}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is polynomial or logarithmic in the arrival time stamp of ratings. This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy via tuning the weight of ratings based on the arrival time stamp. This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by that users tend to assign larger weights to more recent ratings (Rudolph2015, ). Furthermore, this improvement is achieved at simple selections of the weight of ratings. It can be further improved by finer tuning of weights.

8.4. Aggregate Opinion Heterogeneity for Rating Prediction

In this section, we study the benefit of exploiting aggregate opinion heterogeneity for rating prediction. We consider the initial opinion formation model derived in Equation (8). Table 7 shows the RMSE of our R-BE method under the case that the weight Œ≤msubscriptùõΩùëö\beta_{m}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is exponential in opinion levels. In Table 7, we only compare our R-BE method with Herd. One can observe that as we vary the parameter Œ≥ùõæ\gammaitalic_Œ≥ of Œ≤m=exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥‚Å¢m)subscriptùõΩùëöùõæùëö\beta_{m}=\exp(-\gamma m)italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( - italic_Œ≥ italic_m ) from 0.01 to 0.0001, the RMSE can be further reduced over Herd. Similar observations can be found when the weights Œ≤msubscriptùõΩùëö\beta_{m}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is polynomial or logarithmic in rating level mùëömitalic_m as shown in Table 8 and 9. This implies that one can further improve the rating prediction accuracy via tuning the weight of rating levels, i.e., aggregate opinion heterogeneity. This improvement on rating prediction accuracy is supported by that users tend to assign different weights to different rating levels (Rudolph2015, ) This reduction of RMSE is achieved at simple selections on weight for rating levels. Finer tuning of weight may lead to further reduction on the RMSE.

9. Related Work

Online product rating (or review) systems has been studied extensively. A number of works investigated whether and how online product rating systems can benefit sellers and users. Chevalier et al. (Chevalier2006, ) studied the impact of product reviews on the sales of sellers, and they found that positive product reviews can increase the sales. Mudambi et al. (Mudambi2010, ) studied the impact of product reviews on customer‚Äôs purchasing behavior, and found that product reviews are helpful in purchasing decision makings. Similar observations were found by Lackermair et al. (Lackermair2013, ) and Li (Li2013, ). We refer readers to (BrightLocal2016, ; Rudolph2015, ; Shrestha2016, ) for a number of survey studies on the role of product reviews in purchasing decisions.

A variety of works investigated rating (or review) biases. A number of sources that can lead to rating biases has been revealed, e.g., product categories (Guo2015, ), system interfaces (Cosley2003, ), recommendation algorithms (Shafto2016, ), the dynamics of user preferences (Koren2009, ), the improvement of user expertise (McAuley2013, ), etc. To mitigate these biases, a number of methods or algorithms were developed, e.g., (Cosley2003, ; Guo2015, ; Koren2009, ; McAuley2013, ; Shafto2016, ). Our work is closed related to the studied of rating bias from psychological perspectives. Zhang et al. (Zhang2017, ) modeled the assimilate and contrast phenomenon in ratings, and they used the model to improve recommendation accuracy. The herding effects in product ratings were revealed by a number of real-workd experiments (Salganik2006, ; Muchnik2013, ). Krishnan et al. (Krishnan2014, ) and Wang et al. (Wang2014, ) developed models to quantify the effect of herding effects (or social influence biases). Coba et al. (Coba2018, ) did some experiments to study how rating summaries influence user decisions. These works provided evidences for the existence of herding effects in online product rating systems. Built on these evidences, we investigate the convergence of product ratings. We also demonstrate how to utilize these convergence properties to manage product ratings.

10. Conclusion

We develop a framework to manage online product ratings. We formulate a mathematical model to characterize the herding effects, and the decision space to correct product ratings. We identify a class of rating aggregation rules, under which the historical collective opinion converges to the ground-truth collective opinion. We derive a metric to quantify the speed of convergence, which also guides product rating managing. Via theoretical analysis and experiment studies we found: (1) recency aware aggregation rules can significantly speed up the convergence over the unweighted average rule (commonly deployed) especially under strong herding effects; (2) the convergence speed increases in the accuracy of the review selection mechanism but this improvement becomes small when the aggregation rule has a strong recency awareness; (3) recency aware rating aggregation rules can improve the convergence speed in Amazon and TripAdvisor by 41% and 62% respectively.

Appendix A Technical Proofs

Proof of Lemma 1: First we have ùúΩi‚àíùú∂=(1‚àíŒ∑i)‚Å¢ùú∑i+Œ∑i‚Å¢ùú∂‚àíùú∂=(1‚àíŒ∑i)‚Å¢(ùú∑i‚àíùú∂).subscriptùúΩùëñùú∂1subscriptùúÇùëñsubscriptùú∑ùëñsubscriptùúÇùëñùú∂ùú∂1subscriptùúÇùëñsubscriptùú∑ùëñùú∂\bm{\theta}_{i}-\bm{\alpha}=(1-\eta_{i}){\bm{\beta}}_{i}+\eta_{i}{\bm{\alpha}}% -{\bm{\alpha}}=(1-\eta_{i})({\bm{\beta}}_{i}-{\bm{\alpha}}).bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± = ( 1 - italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ± - bold_italic_Œ± = ( 1 - italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± ) . Then if follows that ‚ÄñùúΩi‚àíùú∂‚Äñ=(1‚àíŒ∑i)‚Å¢‚Äñùú∑i‚àíùú∂‚Äñ.normsubscriptùúΩùëñùú∂1subscriptùúÇùëñnormsubscriptùú∑ùëñùú∂||\bm{\theta}_{i}-\bm{\alpha}||=(1-\eta_{i})||{\bm{\beta}}_{i}-{\bm{\alpha}}||.| | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± | | = ( 1 - italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± | | . Therefore, ‚ÄñùúΩi‚àíùú∂‚ÄñnormsubscriptùúΩùëñùú∂||\bm{\theta}_{i}-\bm{\alpha}||| | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± | | is decreasing in Œ∑isubscriptùúÇùëñ\eta_{i}italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. ¬†

Proof of Theorem 1: Let ùêû‚Ñì‚âú[e‚Ñì,1,‚Ä¶,e‚Ñì,M]‚àà‚ÑùM‚âúsubscriptùêû‚Ñìsubscriptùëí‚Ñì1‚Ä¶subscriptùëí‚ÑìùëÄsuperscript‚ÑùùëÄ\mathbf{e}_{\ell}\triangleq[e_{\ell,1},\ldots,e_{\ell,M}]\in\mathbb{R}^{M}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì , italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote an MùëÄMitalic_M dimensional vector, whose ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ellroman_‚Ñì-th entry is 1, i.e., e‚Ñì,‚Ñì=1subscriptùëí‚Ñì‚Ñì1e_{\ell,\ell}=1italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì , roman_‚Ñì end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and all the other entries are zero, i.e., e‚Ñì,m=0,‚àÄm‚â†‚Ñìformulae-sequencesubscriptùëí‚Ñìùëö0for-allùëö‚Ñìe_{\ell,m}=0,\forall m\neq\ellitalic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_‚Ñì , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , ‚àÄ italic_m ‚â† roman_‚Ñì and m‚àà‚Ñ≥ùëö‚Ñ≥m\in\mathcal{M}italic_m ‚àà caligraphic_M. Note that ùêà{Rj=m}subscriptùêàsubscriptùëÖùëóùëö\mathbf{I}_{\{R_{j}=m\}}bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equals to eRj,msubscriptùëísubscriptùëÖùëóùëöe_{R_{j},m}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then we have that

ùú∑isubscriptùú∑ùëñ\displaystyle{\bm{\beta}}_{i}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =[‚àëj=1iwj‚Å¢ùêà{Rj=1}‚àëj=1iwj,‚Ä¶,‚àëj=1iwj‚Å¢ùêà{Rj=M}‚àëj=1iwj]absentsubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùêàsubscriptùëÖùëó1subscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùêàsubscriptùëÖùëóùëÄsubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle=\left[\frac{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}\mathbf{I}_{\{R_{j}=1\}}}{\sum^{i% }_{j=1}w_{j}},\ldots,\frac{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}\mathbf{I}_{\{R_{j}=M\}}}{\sum^{% i}_{j=1}w_{j}}\right]= [ divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , ‚Ä¶ , divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_M } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ]
=[‚àëj=1iwj‚Å¢eRj,1‚àëj=1iwj,‚Ä¶,‚àëj=1iwj‚Å¢eRj,M‚àëj=1iwj]absentsubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùëísubscriptùëÖùëó1subscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùëísubscriptùëÖùëóùëÄsubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle=\left[\frac{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}e_{R_{j},1}}{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}}% ,\ldots,\frac{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}e_{R_{j},M}}{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}}\right]= [ divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , ‚Ä¶ , divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ]
=‚àëj=1iwj‚Å¢ùêûRj‚àëj=1iwj.absentsubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle=\frac{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}\mathbf{e}_{R_{j}}}{\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}}.= divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG .

This implies a useful equation for later proof ‚àëj=1iwj‚Å¢ùêûRj=ùú∑i‚Å¢‚àëj=1iwj.subscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëósubscriptùú∑ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}\mathbf{e}_{R_{j}}={\bm{\beta}}_{i}\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}.‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Then we can derive ùú∑i+1subscriptùú∑ùëñ1\bm{\beta}_{i+1}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows:

ùú∑i+1subscriptùú∑ùëñ1\displaystyle\bm{\beta}_{i+1}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =‚àëj=1i+1wj‚Å¢ùêûRj‚àëj=1i+1wj=wi+1‚Å¢ùêûRi+1+‚àëj=1iwj‚Å¢ùêûRj‚àëj=1i+1wjabsentsubscriptsuperscriptùëñ1ùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëñ1ùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùë§ùëñ1subscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëñ1subscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëñ1ùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle=\frac{\sum^{i+1}_{j=1}w_{j}\mathbf{e}_{R_{j}}}{\sum^{i+1}_{j=1}w% _{j}}=\frac{w_{i+1}\mathbf{e}_{R_{i+1}}+\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_{j}\mathbf{e}_{R_{j}}}% {\sum^{i+1}_{j=1}w_{j}}= divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG
=wi+1‚Å¢ùêûRi+1+ùú∑i‚Å¢‚àëj=1iwj‚àëj=1i+1wjabsentsubscriptùë§ùëñ1subscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëñ1subscriptùú∑ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëñ1ùëó1subscriptùë§ùëó\displaystyle=\frac{w_{i+1}\mathbf{e}_{R_{i+1}}+\bm{\beta}_{i}\sum^{i}_{j=1}w_% {j}}{\sum^{i+1}_{j=1}w_{j}}= divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG
=(1‚àíwi+1‚àëj=1i+1wj)‚Å¢ùú∑i+wi+1‚àëj=1i+1wj‚Å¢ùêûRi+1absent1subscriptùë§ùëñ1subscriptsuperscriptùëñ1ùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùú∑ùëñsubscriptùë§ùëñ1subscriptsuperscriptùëñ1ùëó1subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëñ1\displaystyle=\left(1-\frac{w_{i+1}}{\sum^{i+1}_{j=1}w_{j}}\right)\bm{\beta}_{% i}+\frac{w_{i+1}}{\sum^{i+1}_{j=1}w_{j}}\mathbf{e}_{R_{i+1}}= ( 1 - divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=(1‚àíw~i+1)‚Å¢ùú∑i+w~i+1‚Å¢[Œ≥i‚Å¢ùúΩi+(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢ùú∂+ùêÑi+1],absent1subscript~ùë§ùëñ1subscriptùú∑ùëñsubscript~ùë§ùëñ1delimited-[]subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúΩùëñ1subscriptùõæùëñùú∂subscriptùêÑùëñ1\displaystyle=\left(1-\tilde{w}_{i+1}\right)\bm{\beta}_{i}+\tilde{w}_{i+1}% \left[\gamma_{i}\bm{\theta}_{i}+(1-\gamma_{i})\bm{\alpha}+\mathbf{E}_{i+1}% \right],= ( 1 - over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ± + bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,

where we define ùêÑi+1subscriptùêÑùëñ1\mathbf{E}_{i+1}bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ùêÑi+1‚âúùêûRi+1‚àíŒ≥i‚Å¢ùúΩi‚àí(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢ùú∂.‚âúsubscriptùêÑùëñ1subscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëñ1subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúΩùëñ1subscriptùõæùëñùú∂\mathbf{E}_{i+1}\triangleq\mathbf{e}_{R_{i+1}}-\gamma_{i}\bm{\theta}_{i}-(1-% \gamma_{i})\bm{\alpha}.bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ± . Let HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote a mapping defined as Hi‚Å¢ùú∑i‚âúŒ≥i‚Å¢ùúΩi+(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢ùú∂.‚âúsubscriptùêªùëñsubscriptùú∑ùëñsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúΩùëñ1subscriptùõæùëñùú∂H_{i}\bm{\beta}_{i}\triangleq\gamma_{i}\bm{\theta}_{i}+(1-\gamma_{i})\bm{% \alpha}.italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ± . Then it follows that HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a pseudo-contraction mapping

‚ÄñHi‚Å¢ùú∑i‚àíùú∂‚Äñ=Œ≥i‚Å¢‚ÄñùúΩi‚àíùú∂‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥i‚Å¢‚Äñùú∑i‚àíùú∂‚Äñ‚â§supi‚àà‚Ñï+Œ≥i‚Å¢‚Äñùú∑i‚àíùú∂‚Äñ.normsubscriptùêªùëñsubscriptùú∑ùëñùú∂subscriptùõæùëñnormsubscriptùúΩùëñùú∂subscriptùõæùëñnormsubscriptùú∑ùëñùú∂subscriptsupremumùëñsubscript‚Ñïsubscriptùõæùëñnormsubscriptùú∑ùëñùú∂\|H_{i}\bm{\beta}_{i}-\bm{\alpha}\|=\gamma_{i}\|\bm{\theta}_{i}-\bm{\alpha}\|% \leq\gamma_{i}\|\bm{\beta}_{i}-\bm{\alpha}\|\leq\sup_{i\in\mathbb{N}_{+}}% \gamma_{i}\|\bm{\beta}_{i}-\bm{\alpha}\|.‚à• italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± ‚à• = italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± ‚à• ‚â§ italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± ‚à• ‚â§ roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œ± ‚à• .

Note that we conclude the pseudo-contraction mapping, because supi‚àà‚Ñï+Œ≥i<1subscriptsupremumùëñsubscript‚Ñïsubscriptùõæùëñ1\sup_{i\in\mathbb{N}_{+}}\gamma_{i}<1roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1. Then it follows that HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a unique fixed point ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha}bold_italic_Œ±. One can also check that the error vector ùêÑi+1subscriptùêÑùëñ1\mathbf{E}_{i+1}bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies

ùîº‚Å¢[ùêÑi+1|‚Ñãi]ùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùêÑùëñ1subscript‚Ñãùëñ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{E}_{i+1}|\mathcal{H}_{i}]blackboard_E [ bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] =ùîº‚Å¢[ùêûRi+1|‚Ñãi]‚àíŒ≥i‚Å¢ùúΩi‚àí(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢ùú∂absentùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùêûsubscriptùëÖùëñ1subscript‚ÑãùëñsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúΩùëñ1subscriptùõæùëñùú∂\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{e}_{R_{i+1}}|\mathcal{H}_{i}]-\gamma_{i}\bm{% \theta}_{i}-(1-\gamma_{i})\bm{\alpha}= blackboard_E [ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ±
=Œ≥i‚Å¢ùúΩi+(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢ùú∂‚àíŒ≥i‚Å¢ùú∑i‚àí(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢ùú∂=ùüé.absentsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúΩùëñ1subscriptùõæùëñùú∂subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùú∑ùëñ1subscriptùõæùëñùú∂0\displaystyle=\gamma_{i}\bm{\theta}_{i}+(1-\gamma_{i})\bm{\alpha}-\gamma_{i}% \bm{\beta}_{i}-(1-\gamma_{i})\bm{\alpha}=\mathbf{0}.= italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ± - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_Œ± = bold_0 .

Furthermore, ùîº‚Å¢[Ei+1,m2|‚Ñãi]‚â§[Œ≥i‚Å¢Œ∏i,m+(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢Œ±m]2+ùîº‚Å¢[ùêà{Ri+1=m}2|‚Ñãi]‚â§2.ùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏2ùëñ1ùëösubscript‚Ñãùëñsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúÉùëñùëö1subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùõºùëö2ùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptsuperscriptùêà2subscriptùëÖùëñ1ùëösubscript‚Ñãùëñ2\mathbb{E}[E^{2}_{i+1,m}|\mathcal{H}_{i}]\leq[\gamma_{i}\theta_{i,m}+(1-\gamma% _{i})\alpha_{m}]^{2}+\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{I}^{2}_{\{R_{i+1}=m\}}|\mathcal{H}_{i}% ]\leq 2.blackboard_E [ italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ‚â§ [ italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + blackboard_E [ bold_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ‚â§ 2 . Lastly, note that w~isubscript~ùë§ùëñ\tilde{w}_{i}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies ‚àëi=1‚àûw~i=‚àû,‚àëi=1‚àûw~i2<‚àû.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëñ1subscript~ùë§ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùëñ1subscriptsuperscript~ùë§2ùëñ\sum^{\infty}_{i=1}\tilde{w}_{i}=\infty,\sum^{\infty}_{i=1}\tilde{w}^{2}_{i}<\infty.‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àû , ‚àë start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ‚àû . Then it follows that ùú∑isubscriptùú∑ùëñ\bm{\beta}_{i}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to the unique fixed point of HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT almost surely. Then it follows that ‚Ñô‚Å¢[limi‚Üí‚àûùú∑i=ùú∂]=1.‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscript‚Üíùëñsubscriptùú∑ùëñùú∂1\mathbb{P}[\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\bm{\beta}_{i}=\bm{\alpha}]=1.blackboard_P [ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚Üí ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Œ± ] = 1 . ¬†

Proof of Theorem 2: Note that the number of misbehaving ratings is finite and the index of the last misbehaving rating is iksubscriptùëñùëòi_{k}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us now consider ùú∑isubscriptùú∑ùëñ\bm{\beta}_{i}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all i=ik+1,‚Ä¶,‚àûùëñsubscriptùëñùëò1‚Ä¶i=i_{k}+1,\ldots,\inftyitalic_i = italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , ‚Ä¶ , ‚àû. Note that from the proof of Theorem 1, one can observe that the convergence of ùú∑isubscriptùú∑ùëñ\bm{\beta}_{i}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is invariant of the initial historical collective opinion, i.e., ùú∑1subscriptùú∑1\bm{\beta}_{1}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore the sequence of historical collective opinion ùú∑ik,ùú∑ik+1,‚Ä¶,‚àûsubscriptùú∑subscriptùëñùëòsubscriptùú∑subscriptùëñùëò1‚Ä¶\bm{\beta}_{i_{k}},\bm{\beta}_{i_{k}+1},\ldots,\inftybold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , ‚àû still converges to ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha}bold_italic_Œ± almost surely. ¬†

Proof of Theorem 3: Without loss of generality, let us consider one entry of the historical collective opinion ùú∑isubscriptùú∑ùëñ\bm{\beta}_{i}bold_italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., Œ≤i,msubscriptùõΩùëñùëö\beta_{i,m}italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. From the proof of Theorem 1, we have that Œ≤i+1,m=(1‚àíw~i+1)‚Å¢Œ≤i,m+w~i+1‚Å¢ùêà{Ri+1=m}.subscriptùõΩùëñ1ùëö1subscript~ùë§ùëñ1subscriptùõΩùëñùëösubscript~ùë§ùëñ1subscriptùêàsubscriptùëÖùëñ1ùëö\beta_{i+1,m}=(1-\tilde{w}_{i+1})\beta_{i,m}+\tilde{w}_{i+1}\mathbf{I}_{\{R_{i% +1}=m\}}.italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Then it follows that

ùîº‚Å¢[Œ≤i+1,m|‚Ñãi]ùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùõΩùëñ1ùëösubscript‚Ñãùëñ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\beta_{i+1,m}|\mathcal{H}_{i}]blackboard_E [ italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]
=(1‚àíw~i+1)‚Å¢Œ≤i,m+w~i+1‚Å¢[Œ≥i‚Å¢Œ∏i,m+(1‚àíŒ≥i)‚Å¢Œ±m]absent1subscript~ùë§ùëñ1subscriptùõΩùëñùëösubscript~ùë§ùëñ1delimited-[]subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúÉùëñùëö1subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùõºùëö\displaystyle=(1-\tilde{w}_{i+1})\beta_{i,m}+\tilde{w}_{i+1}[\gamma_{i}\theta_% {i,m}+(1-\gamma_{i})\alpha_{m}]= ( 1 - over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Œ≤ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]

+(1‚àíŒ≥i)Œ±m]\displaystyle+(1-\gamma_{i})\alpha_{m}]+ ( 1 - italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]
